Subject: Re: [neat] Bilateral Symmetry and NEAT
X-Yahoo-Group-Post: member; u=7192225; y=Di85rztaWPWjxNWLmjXiGfzoM24fiUZePSorGrX1Ibv0Eke5NQ

> Hi all,

Hi Derek,

> Just thought I'd post an update on what Philip and I
> have been working on
> lately, to get some feedback, but also to help me
> articulate the
> implementation and some of the ideas behind it
> (since I'm in grad school now
> and will have to explain this to a lot of people
> soon anyway).
> 
> 
> 
> I have to do a first year project as part of the PhD
> program I'm in right
> now, Cognitive Science at the University of
> Louisiana at Lafayette.  I
> decided to focus on a particular aspect of indirect
> encoding in the context
> of NEAT, specifically bilateral symmetry.  Most
> animals exhibit a high
> degree of bilateral symmetry in their overall body
> plan, as well as their
> neural systems.  It seemed like a logical starting
> point for a foray into
> indirect encoding.

I think you are correct in the general idea, but I
have to qualify the idea that animals have bilateral
symmetry in their neural systems.

Clearly at a very broad level vertibrates do have
bilateral neural symmetry, but the different functions
of the left and right hemispheres would seem to
suggest than the symmetry does not extend into their
fine detail.

And any neural net that we can practically construct
today, is necessarily only equivalent to some fine
detail from a vertibrate brain.

OTOH, very simple creatures, C. elegans and hydra, for
example, do have nets on a similar scale to yours, and
I that some of them do exhibit symmetry (e.g. I think
C elegans has bilateral symmetry.  Hydra are not
overall symmetric (having buds) but each sub-section
may have radial symmetry?)

Just something you might want to bear in mind when you
are defending your work...

> Anyway, I'm interested in several theoretical
> questions:
>
> To what extent is bilateral symmetry in an agent's
> neural system necessary?

I'm a little cautious with the phrasing of that.

I would say that it is not at all "necessary".

The proper question should be:

"What if any, advantages can bilateral symmetry give
to an evolving agent?"

And that has to be taken in the context of whether the
task domain has symmetry or not.

> And for what kinds of cognitive tasks?

Note that there are different ways that the domain
symmetry could be relevent:

no symmetry
bilateral symmetric agent in asymetric world (most
common)
bilateral symmetric agent and world
higher symmetry in agent and/or world
 
> To what extent is contralateral connectivity
> (connections which cross the
> midline of the neural system, i.e., are
> interhemispheric) important, as
> opposed to ipsilateral connectivity (connections
> which do not cross the
> midline, i.e., are intrahemispheric)?

Presumably it is totally necessary, otherwise you have
two separate neural nets...?

> To try to start answering some of these questions,
> we extended NEAT in the
> following ways:

[snip]

> When constructing the initial network, all
> asymmetrical neurons will default
> to the "left" of the network.  So the network now
> has a spatial structure,
> whereas before it was arbitrary.

Conceptually, I guess it is of no consequence where
the asymmetrical neurons are considered to be.  But
personally I would find the system more intuitive if
they were imagined to be "in the middle"...

> So all neuron genes now have a symmetry attribute,
> and all connections have
> 2 new attributes, symmetry and lateralization
> (indicating whether they cross
> the midline or not).

I'm a little confused here, how can connections have a
symmetry attribute that is different from the nodes
they like.  e.g. what would it mean to put a symmetric
link between two asymmetric neurones, or vice-versa?

Shouldn't they just "inherit" the symmetry of the
nodes?

I guess when you have symmetric inputs and outputs,
you could imagine you have three cases: lateral,
translateral and both.  But wouldn't the last case be
achieved by having two connections between those two
nodes (one lateral and one translateral)?

> asymmetric.  If the mutation occurs on top of a
> symmetric connection, the
> new resulting neurons and connections will have the
> same symmetry and
> lateralization attributes of the connection gene
> they replaced.

Isn't this last sentance a bit odd, e.g. if you insert
a node into a translateral connection, then if the two
new connections are both translateral, the overall
effect is lateral (connecting right->left->right)?

> Add connection mutations are fairly complicated. 
> There are 2 new mutation
> rates, which control the amount of symmetry and
> lateralization in the newly
> mutated connections.  First, the add connection
> mutation rate determines how
> many new connections should be added.  Of those, the
> symmetry rate
> determines the ratio that are symmetric.  Of each of
> those two ratios, the
> lateralization rate determines the ratio of new
> contralateral/ipsilateral
> connections.

Please read my terms "lateral" and "translateral" as
ipsilateral and contralateral respectively :)

> For a mutation between 2 symmetrical neurons, 
> there are four actual neurons in the resulting 
> network, and we allow 6 possible types of 
> connectivity to mutate:

symmetrical/ipsilateral    ||
symmetric/contralateral    X
asymmetric/ipsilateral left   |-
asymmetric/ipsilateral right   -|
asymmetric/contralateral left  /
asymmetric/contralateral right  \

Ah!  I see the answer to my previous question, so if I
read you correctly, you are specifying the nodes in a
"pre-symmetry" format, and then adding symmetry during
network creation according to the symmetry flag on the
node-gene.  But for the connections you are specifying
their source and target neurons from the post-symmetry
pool?

That seems like a very odd choice to me.  I had
assumed up to this point that the node and connection
genes were both "pre-symmetry" and that you were
creating the symmetry of the connections are network
creation time as well.


With regard to your current scheme, suppose you have
two nodes:


1 - hidden, symmetric
2
 - hidden, symmetric

at network creation time these become:

1left		1right


2left		2right

And connection genes can separately specify that they
are 1left to 2left, or 1right to 2right...

But not 1 left to 2right? err, actually I don't get
what you mean, there seems to be some ambiguity in how
the connection gene targets and flags interact...

Maybe you could explain some more?

--

On the whole, however, I like the scope and direction
of this project a lot.  I spent some time last year
thinking about symmetry in evolving systems, and
particularly about how systems might discover it for
themselves.

I didn't get that thought to a state of completion, 
but a project like this, where you gift the system
with som symmetry, seems like an ideal starting point.

Not so different from my SLEAT stuff, except in for
that my symmetry is the squares of a TicTacToe
board...


	Ian
